review.title: Learning Large-Scale Topological Maps Using Sum-Product Networks
review.abstract: In order to perform complex actions in human environments, an autonomous robot needs the ability to understand the environment, that is, to gather and maintain spatial knowledge. Topological map is commonly used for representing large scale, global maps such as floor plans. Although much work has been done in topological map extraction, we have found little previous work on the problem of learning the topological map using a probabilistic model. Learning a topological map means learning the structure of the large-scale space and dependency between places, for example, how the evidence of a group of places influence the attributes of other places. This is an important step towards planning complex actions in the environment. In this thesis, we consider the problem of using probabilistic deep learning model to learn the topological map, which is essentially a sparse undirected graph where nodes represent places annotated with their semantic attributes (e.g. place category). We propose to use a novel probabilistic deep model, Sum-Product Networks (SPNs), due to their unique properties. We present two methods for learning topological maps using SPNs: the place grid method and the template-based method. We contribute an algorithm that builds SPNs for graphs using template models. Our experiments evaluate the ability of our models to enable robots to infer semantic attributes and detect maps with novel semantic attribute arrangements. Our results demonstrate their understanding of the topological map structure and spatial relations between places.

sections.heading: 1.1 Constraints
sections.text: In this paper, we focus on the category of place as the only semantic attribute for a place. Our basic idea is this: In view of the potential use of the learned model, it would certainly be helpful to provide other information such as object types in a place or the low-threshold sensory information. However, our goal in this work is to evaluate the problem of learning topological maps separately. Of course, the proposed methods cover the case where more semantic characteristics or sensory information are considered, which is one direction for future work.

sections.heading: 1.2 Thesis outline
sections.text: Section 2 - Related Work We review related work in the use of topological maps as part of spatial knowledge, learning topological maps, and newer machine learning techniques to model graphs. Section 3 - Background We discuss details of the theoretical background to our work. First, we describe details of sum product networks. Then, we present an overview of the spatial hierarchy of Deep Affordance. Finally, we formalize the concept of topological maps and describe the method by which we extract topological maps. Section 4 - Problem definition & proposed solutions We formalize the problem we are trying to solve in this thesis. Then, we describe the details of the two presented methods that model topological maps using SPNs: the space grid method and the template-based method.Section 5 - Experiments We describe the dataset, methodology, and results of our experiments. Section 6 - Conclusions & future work We conclude our thesis by publishing a summary of the presented methods and finally publishing the results in Item 2.

sections.heading: 3 Background
sections.text: In this section, I will give the background to this thesis in detail. First, I will describe in detail the properties of sum-product networks (SPNs), how to draw conclusions and how to learn the parameters and structure of the network. Next, I will describe the Deep Affordance Spatial Hierarchy (DASH), the spatial representation of knowledge that we use to enable mobile robots to understand the environment. Finally, I will describe topological maps for interiors in general and how topological maps are generated in DASH.

sections.heading: 3.3 Topological Maps
sections.text: A topological map is a graph that captures important locations on the map and their connectivity. In the context of robotics, the nodes in this graph are the places accessible by the robot, and edges indicate the affordability of navigation between locations, i.e. the feasibility of navigating from one place to another. Figure 1 shows examples of simplified topological maps. As already discussed, the topological map is used as a layer to capture the geometry of the map and the connectivity between locations in the DASH. The authors of DASH [22] also describe a mapping algorithm that builds a topological map. As the robot explores an environment, the mapping algorithm expands the topological map by adding placeholders [23] as nodes, according to a probability formulation as consequence properties P (E | G) = 1 Z-i-shaped models of egg-shaped places (egg).

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Challenges
sections.text: There are several challenges in modeling topological maps due to their scale and variability; a complete map of a workspace can contain dozens of nodes and hundreds of edges; the number of locations in one map is likely to differ from that in another; different topological maps can represent environments of different dimensions; the structure of locations in one map can appear very different from another; and finally, because our topological maps can encode the geometric structure described above, different topological maps can also be rotated differently for similar environments, as the underlying metric maps created by SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping) can be rotated differently as a whole.

sections.heading: 4.1 Problem Statement
sections.text: Our problem is this: In view of datasets of topological maps with an unknown number of nodes per map, we would like to construct sum product networks so that the resulting model is able to demonstrate its understanding of the spatial relationships of categories. It can demonstrate this capability in several ways. For example, if we provide a topological map instance with missing semantic information, the model should reasonably predict what the missing information is. Moreover, if we provide a topological map instance with strange category arrangements (e.g. corridor nodes called bureau), the model should be able to detect this novelty. In Section 5, we describe experiments that are being conducted to test this capability.

sections.heading: 4.2 Place Grid Method
sections.text: To meet the challenge of topological maps being of different sizes and shapes, we present a simple idea, which consists in mapping them on fixed-size grids. A grid can be considered a generic representation of topological maps. It approaches the topological map, but preserves most of the neighborhood relationships between places. It is easy to use SPN to model this grid. Using the algorithm in 3.1.4, we can create an SPN for the grid, which then indirectly models topological maps as a whole. 9

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Motivation
sections.text: One shortcoming of the space grid method is its dependence on a predefined size and resolution of the grid; choosing the right dimensions and resolution is a difficult task, and usually the parameters chosen cannot be generalized well for other invisible topological map examples. Moreover, the grid itself is in the middle between accuracy and approximation: although the grid is metric, the cells do not accurately represent the location of the locations, which can affect the quality of the conclusions. To some extent, it is unnecessary to have an accurate absolute representation of the topological map, since (1) it is difficult to maintain this accuracy given the variability of topological maps, and (2) topological maps are usually used in conjunction with metric maps for robotic planning and navigation, which serve as a reference for high-level planning. Therefore, we propose a template-based relative representation of the topological map that models a certain basic structure of a chart and extends it as needed.

sections.heading: 5.1 Data Collection
sections.text: To support the larger goal of our research, to learn the Deep Affordance Spatial Hierarchy (DASH), we collected a large dataset of fully commented sensory (RGB, laser rangefinder measurements, odometry), local and virtual scans, a low representation of the environment immediately in front of the robot. For this work, we used this dataset to generate topological maps with nodes labeled by place category.The dataset consists of 100 sequences and a total of 11 different floor plans in three buildings at three different locations: Stockholm, Sweden, Freiburg, Germany and Saarbrücken, Germany. The summary of the sequences is in Table 1. For each sequence among the data types included, there is a corresponding canonical map and an annotated floor plan on which the annotated localized poses are generated using adaptive Monte Carlo Localibration (AMCL) with a frequency of 30 Hz. We use the canonical map and the stock topographic maps, where we use the larger, topographical spaces.

sections.heading: 5.2 Methodology

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Software
sections.text: We used LibSPN [21], a Python library that implements learning and deduction with SPNs on GPUs. This library provides the functionality to generate a dense SPN structure using the random decomposition method described in Section 3.1.4. We use this functionality to generate SPN both on a placeholder and on templates.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Experiments for Place Grid Method
sections.text: We converted topological maps from Stockholm into space grids. We used space grids of the size of 15 rows by 10 columns with a resolution of 1.5 m per cell. The resolution is lower than the 1.0 m of the desired space separation in topological maps to ensure the connectivity of the places when they are placed in the network, as suggested in Section 4.2.1. Since the size of our data set is not very large, we have reduced the number of space categories to four: entrance, corridor, small office and large office. so that we can better evaluate the learning of structure and dependence. Note that for other categories, such as kitchen and meeting room, we do not distinguish them from the unknown space category. To check the consistency of the space network method, we used cross-validation by forming the network on three floors and testing them on the other, for each combination of the four floors in the Stockholm data set.

sections.heading: 5.2.3 Experiments for Template-Based Method
sections.text: As described in Section 4.3, during the training we train an SPN for a single template or hierarchy of templates. Therefore, we have created a dataset in which each example is an assignment of the template variables. The dataset is created from both Stockholm sequences and Freiburg sequences, because the topological relationships of the place categories are generally the same in different environments. [1] We do this by partitioning the available topological maps using the templates. Partitioning operation is performed ten times for each topological map to capture different combinations of nodes. During the test, we construct a complete SPN for each test instance according to the algorithm described in Section 4.3.2. Similar to the experiments for the placeholder method, we also include parts of the topological map and ask the model to derive its attributes. As the templates only take into account the connectivity of locations and the location category is the only semantic attribute we exercise on the basis that we expect the template to be based on multiple templates, but only the template for the current behavior we expect the template to be based on several SPN, as the current one.

sections.text: The results are shown in Figure 11. The images on the left are the results of training samples, and those on the right are the results of validation samples. The first three lines show the results of map completion in place with different closed regions. The last line shows the results of map completion in place with randomly locked cells. These results suggest that the model learns the relationships between space categories and general map structure to some degree. It is able to place door nodes between corridor and rooms. It is also able to learn that corridors stretch along the same line and not mix up different room categories.

sections.text: We performed the experiment to complete the missing value on three sequences.7 Figure 14 shows the result of one of the sequences in which we skipped places with an unknown category and used a hierarchy of templates. We found that typically a template hierarchy yields better results than using only a single template. Therefore, the model is of the view that it is appropriate not to place a door opening cell between an unknown (background) cell and a corridor cell, as this background cell refers to a category that we may have limited due to the amount of time.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion & Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we have motivated the importance of learning spatial representation for autonomous mobile robotics. We have described the role of the topological map and discussed its generation in the context of the Deep Affordance Spatial Hierarchy. Subsequently, we have presented two methods that can enable learning of topological maps using summary product networks. Finally, we have described experiments and presented results demonstrating the effect of learning for each method. Indeed, there is work to improve each of the two methods. In particular, in the template-based method, the current method only takes into account the networking of places and place categories as the only semantic attribute. We want to introduce more complexity into the templates and consider more information (such as laser range measurements) when learning the SPN templates. 21

metadata.abstractText: In order to perform complex actions in human environments, an autonomous robot needs the ability to understand the environment, that is, to gather and maintain spatial knowledge. Topological map is commonly used for representing large scale, global maps such as floor plans. Although much work has been done in topological map extraction, we have found little previous work on the problem of learning the topological map using a probabilistic model. Learning a topological map means learning the structure of the large-scale space and dependency between places, for example, how the evidence of a group of places influence the attributes of other places. This is an important step towards planning complex actions in the environment. In this thesis, we consider the problem of using probabilistic deep learning model to learn the topological map, which is essentially a sparse undirected graph where nodes represent places annotated with their semantic attributes (e.g. place category). We propose to use a novel probabilistic deep model, Sum-Product Networks (SPNs) [20], due to their unique properties. We present two methods for learning topological maps using SPNs: the place grid method and the template-based method. We contribute an algorithm that builds SPNs for graphs using template models. Our experiments evaluate the ability of our models to enable robots to infer semantic attributes and detect maps with novel semantic attribute arrangements. Our results demonstrate their understanding of the topological map structure and spatial relations between places.
